perturbation.original_text: All information, knowledge and know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System (“Confidential Information”) is deemed confidential, except for information that Member can demonstrate came to Member’s attention by lawful means prior to disclosure to Member; or which, at the time of the disclosure to Member, had become a part of the public domain.
perturbation.changed_text: All information, knowledge and know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System (“Confidential Information”) is deemed confidential. Information is not considered Confidential Information if Member can demonstrate it came to Member’s attention by lawful means prior to disclosure to Member; or if, at the time of disclosure to Member, it was already part of the public domain and Member can prove Franchisor gave public access to the Confidential Information.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of 'Confidential Information' excludes information that was already in the public domain at the time of disclosure. The modified definition adds the clause that the public information must be proven to be given access by the franchisor, which creates a contradiction because the original definition did not include this condition, broadening the definition of what's confidential based on who released it. It's now unclear if public knowledge obtained elsewhere but released by the franchisor is considered confidential.

perturbation.original_text: (c) Member covenants and agrees that during the Post-Term Period (defined below), except as otherwise approved in writing by Franchisor, Member shall not, either directly or indirectly, own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate, within a three (3) mile radius of the premises of your Franchised Business or within a three (3) mile radius of any Franchised Business then-operating or under construction to operate under the System.
perturbation.changed_text: (c) Member covenants and agrees that during the Post-Term Period (defined below), except as otherwise approved in writing by Franchisor, Member shall not, either directly or indirectly, own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate, within a three (3) mile radius of the premises of your Franchised Business. This restriction does not apply to any Franchised Business then-operating or under construction to operate under the System.
perturbation.explanation: The original non-compete clause prohibits involvement in competitive businesses within a 3-mile radius of *any* Pizza Fusion franchise. The modified version removes the restriction based on other existing or under construction franchises, narrowing the scope of the non-compete. This creates a contradiction because it's now unclear if the member can engage in competitive activities near *other* Pizza Fusion franchises after termination. If they are not running the franchised business that member was employed by, can they now act on other franchised locations?

perturbation.original_text: (d) As used in this Agreement, the term “Post-Term Period” shall mean a continuous uninterrupted period of two (2) years from the date of: (a) a transfer permitted under Section 14 of the Franchise Agreement; (b) expiration or termination of the Franchise Agreement (regardless of the cause for termination); (c) termination of Member’s employment with Franchisee; and/or (d) a final order of a duly authorized arbitrator, panel of arbitrators, or a court of competent jurisdiction (after all appeals have been taken) with respect to any of the foregoing or with respect to the enforcement of this Agreement; either directly or indirectly (through, on behalf of, or in conjunction with any persons, partnership, corporation or entity).
perturbation.changed_text: (d) As used in this Agreement, the term “Post-Term Period” shall mean a continuous uninterrupted period of two (2) years from the date of: (a) a transfer permitted under Section 14 of the Franchise Agreement; (b) expiration or termination of the Franchise Agreement due to franchisee's breach; (c) termination of Member’s employment with Franchisee for gross misconduct; and/or (d) a final order of a duly authorized arbitrator, panel of arbitrators, or a court of competent jurisdiction (after all appeals have been taken) with respect to any of the foregoing or with respect to the enforcement of this Agreement; either directly or indirectly (through, on behalf of, or in conjunction with any persons, partnership, corporation or entity).
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of 'Post-Term Period' includes expiration or termination of the Franchise Agreement regardless of the reason or how it happened. The changed version limits the expiration or termination of franchise agreement if that happened due to franchisee's breach. Also, it limits the member’s employment with Franchisee is terminated for gross misconduct. This means if the franchisee did not breach, and the member did not act with gross misconduct, it is unclear if there is a post-term period.
